sen.j: 堺町通（さかいまちどおり）は京都市内の南北の通りの一つ。
sen.e: The Sakaimachi-dori Street is a north-south running street of Kyoto City.
The Sakaimachi-dori Street is a street running north-south through Kyoto City.
The Sakaimachi-dori Street is a street running north-south through Kyoto City.

sen.j: 北は丸太町通から南は五条通まで。
sen.e: It extends from the Marutamachi-dori Street to the Gojo-dori Street.
It extends from Marutamachi-dori Street to Gojo-dori Street.
It extends from Marutamachi-dori Street to Gojo-dori Street.

sen.j: 途中仏光寺通と高辻通の間で分断されている。
sen.e: It is divided between the Bukkoji-dori Street and the Takatsuji-dori.
It is divided between Bukkoji-dori Street and Takatsuji-dori.
It is divided between Bukkoji-dori Street and Takatsuji-dori.

sen.j: 平安京には存在せず、豊臣秀吉による天正の地割で新設された通りである。
sen.e: It did not exist in Heiankyo and was built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI according to his Tensho zoning.
It did not exist in Heiankyo and was built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI according to his Tensho zoning policy.
It did not exist in Heiankyo and was built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI according to his Tensho zoning policy.

sen.j: 通り名の由来は、戦国時代_(日本)に京都の町が衰退していたころには、このあたりが京の街と田畑との境界であったこととされる。
sen.e: During the period of civil war (Japan) when Kyoto was in its twilight, the street is said to have provided a boundary defining downtown and farms, which became the origin of the name of the street.

During the period of civil war (Japan) when Kyoto was in its twilight, the street is said to have provided a boundary which defined downtown and farms, and became the origin for the name of the street.

During the Sengoku period (period of Warring States, Jaoan) when Kyoto was in its twilight, the street is said to have provided a boundary which defined downtown and farms, and became the origin for the name of the street.
sen.cmt: 「戦国時代_(日本)」を統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 通りの北端に京都御苑の堺町御門がある。
sen.e: Sakaimachigomon of the Kyoto Imperial Palace is located at the northern end of the street.
Sakaimachigomon of the Kyoto Imperial Palace is located at the northern end of the street.
Sakaimachigomon of the Kyoto Imperial Palace is located at the northern end of the street.

sen.j: 江戸時代には通り沿いに多くの材木商があり、今も「杉屋町」・「丸木材木町」などの町名が残っている。
sen.e: The town names of "Sugiyacho" and "Marukizaimokucho" remain because many lumber dealers were located along this street during the Edo era.
The town names of "Sugiyacho" and "Marukizaimokucho" remain because many lumber dealers were located along this street during the Edo era.
The town names of 'Sugiyacho' and 'Marukizaimokucho' remain because many lumber dealers were located along this street during the Edo period.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、Edo periodに修正

sen.j: 京都御苑堺町御門 丸太町
